unnormalised: Okay, folks, let's talk about something thrilling... healthcare identifiers! I know, I know, sounds about as exciting as watching paint dry. But trust me, under the bureaucratic layers, there's a goldmine of absurdity.
normalised: Okay, folks, let's talk about something thrilling... healthcare identifiers! I know, I know, sounds about as exciting as watching paint dry. But trust me, under the bureaucratic layers, there's a goldmine of absurdity.

unnormalised: So, you’ve got your Aadhaar card, right? That’s like your national identity, the key to everything from getting a SIM card to proving you exist. But did you know that the Ayushman Bharat Health Account (ABHA) ID, aka your healthcare identifier, is kinda like Aadhaar’s slightly awkward cousin? You can link them, but they're still separate entities. Think of it as being invited to both your aunt’s *haldi* ceremony and the actual wedding – similar vibes, but distinct events. Mine is linked – ABHA: 1427-9876-5432-1011. Hope I remember that next time I need it.
normalised: So, you’ve got your Aadhaar card, right? That’s like your national identity, the key to everything from getting a S-I-M card to proving you exist. But did you know that the Ayushman Bharat Health Account (A-B-H-A) I-D, also known as your healthcare identifier, is kinda like Aadhaar’s slightly awkward cousin? You can link them, but they're still separate entities. Think of it as being invited to both your aunt’s *haldi* ceremony and the actual wedding – similar vibes, but distinct events. Mine is linked – A-B-H-A: one thousand four hundred and twenty seven, nine thousand eight hundred and seventy six, five thousand four hundred and thirty two, one thousand and eleven. Hope I remember that next time I need it.

unnormalised: Then there’s the whole insurance thing. My private health insurance card has a totally different number! Like, seriously? Why can’t we all just agree on one magical number to rule them all? My ICICI Lombard policy number, for example, is CP/12345/2023/6789. Trying to remember all these feels like trying to juggle burning *rotis* at a wedding feast.
normalised: Then there’s the whole insurance thing. My private health insurance card has a totally different number! Like, seriously? Trying to remember all these feels like trying to juggle burning *rotis* at a wedding feast.

unnormalised: And don't even get me started on employer-provided insurance. Suddenly, I'm staring at a whole new alphanumeric code that looks like it was generated by a caffeinated chimpanzee on a keyboard. My company's group medical insurance card from Star Health has this GEM ID: STAR-EMP-0001-2024. Good luck deciphering that when you're doubled over in pain trying to claim something!

Good luck deciphering that when you're doubled over in pain trying to claim something!

unnormalised: The sheer number of these identifiers is enough to give anyone a stress-induced migraine – which, ironically, would require… wait for it… another identifier to get treatment! It's a vicious cycle! I’m half expecting my chaiwallah to start issuing loyalty cards with their own unique ID numbers just to track my daily consumption. I'd probably have a chai ID of: CHAI-DL-123-456.
